Sharks possess a remarkable ability to detect electrical signals in their environment.<[silence]> This capability is facilitated by specialized sensory organs known as the ampullae of Lorenzini.<[silence]> These small, jelly-filled pores are located primarily around the shark's snout.<[silence]> They are sensitive to minute changes in electric fields, allowing sharks to perceive the bioelectric fields produced by other organisms.<[silence]>

The ampullae of Lorenzini are connected to the nervous system, transmitting information to the brain.<[silence]> This sensory input aids in navigation, prey detection, and even social interactions.<[silence]> Sharks can detect electrical signals as faint as one billionth of a volt.<[silence]> This sensitivity is particularly useful in murky waters where visibility is limited.<[silence]>
